required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Application of KANG FU PEN in Radical Concurrent Radiotherapy and Chemotherapy for Cervical Cancer to Prevent and Treat Radiation-induced Rectal Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Application of KANG FU PEN (Protective Irrigation Solution Against Rays) in Radical Concurrent Radiotherapy and Chemotherapy for Cervical Cancer to Prevent and Treat Radiation-induced Rectal Injury：a Multicenter, Prospective, Randomized Trail

collaborator.agency: Cancer Institute and Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences
Sichuan Cancer Hospital and Research Institute
Xijing Hospital Attached Air Force Medical University
Guizhou Cancer Hospital (The Affiliated Cancer Hospital of Guizhou Medical University)
Xiangya Hospital of Central South University

brief_summary.textblock: A total of 520 cases will be randomly divided into Kang Fu Pen (liquid dressing) enema intervention group (experimental group) and non-enema intervention group (control group), according to the ratio of 1:1.

detailed_description.textblock:
All patients are planned to receive radical concurrent chemoradiotherapy. Intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) will be used for external irradiation, with a dose of 45-50.4Gy /25-28 fractions. Combined three-dimensional intracavitary/interstitial (IC/IS) brachytherapy was applied. The preferred dose fraction plan is 6Gy*5 fractions, or 7Gy*4 fractions. Whether to adopt supplement radiotherapy can be decided by the tumor regression. Cisplatin 40 mg/m2 is recommended as the first choice for concurrent chemotherapy, and TP or TC can also be considered. Single-drug weekly therapy should be completed for at least 3 cycles, and combined 3-week regimen should be completed for at least 1 cycle.
Experimental group: from three days before radiotherapy to one week after radiotherapy, Kang Fu Pen (recombinant human superoxide dismutase) retention enema, 50ml/ time, once every other day. When rectal mucosa II degree reactions (NCI-CTCAE 5.0) occur, it is changed to 1 day/time until 1 week after mucosal remission.
Control group: 3 days before radiotherapy to the end of radiotherapy, no drug retention enema was used.

primary_outcome.measure: Degree of rectal mucosal injury caused by acute radiation
primary_outcome.description: the incidence of Vienna rectoscopy score ≥2 within 1 week after radiotherapy. Vienna rectoscopy score was used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Degree of rectal injury caused by chronic radiation
secondary_outcome.description: incidence of RTOG score ≥2 at 3 to 24 months after radiotherapy. If the RTOG score ≥2 at 3 to 24 months after radiotherapy, rectoscopy will be used to evaluate the degree. If the RTOG score is 0 or 1, clinical classification is enough.
EORTC QLQ-C30 (V3.0) was used to score quality of life before, during, and after radiotherapy.
Overall survival (OS) is defined as the time interval from randomization to death from any cause or, if no death, to the last follow-up.

Progression-free survival (PFS) is defined as the time between randomization and the occurrence of local or regional recurrence, or distant metastasis, or death from any cause, based on the time of the first event and, if none of these events occurred, to the last follow-up.

intervention.description: FU PEN: anti-radiation spray (liquid dressing) treatment which is a protective irrigation solution against rays
